image.altText: Brain scans showing amyloid in Alzheimer's disease, with the shape of a head filled in with colour representing scan results

items.synopsis: Decades of research on Alzheimer's disease have started to come to fruition, with at least three new drugs demonstrating the first glimmers of promise.

title.children: 'Major breakthrough': Landmark study shows best signs yet that Alzheimer's can be slowed

image.altText: A man in a police hat talking at a press conference

items.synopsis: New South Wales Fire and Rescue Commissioner Paul Baxter was let go from the organisation on Monday afternoon.

title.children: NSW Fire and Rescue Commissioner Paul Baxter sacked by minister

image.altText: An image of Sydney's CBD, with people walking, faces not visible, carrying shopping bags.

items.synopsis: Inflation is creating inflation. Unlike previous episodes where higher prices sparked wage breakouts, a large portion of our inflation is being driven by interest rate hikes, writes Ian Verrender.

title.children: Fossil fuel prices have collapsed. So why are we paying more for electricity?

image.altText: A buckled and damaged bridge

items.synopsis: The day started with two mysterious explosions on Putin's beloved Kerch bridge and ended with Russia withdrawing from a crucial deal to allow Ukrainian grain to pass through the Black Sea. Here's everything we know.

title.children: A furious Putin, a busted bridge and a torn-up deal: Russia and Ukraine's wild 24 hours explained

image.altText: A number of people cross an intersection in Brisbane's CBD. Behind them are office buildings.

items.synopsis: The shift to working remotely has led to a significant drop in office property prices, which could affect our retirement savings given superannuation funds invest more than $425 billion in unlisted assets.

title.children: Flexible work is causing office property prices to fall — and potentially your retirement savings, as well

image.altText: A soldier in protective camouflage gear ducks and holds his helmet as a mortar explodes into the sky behind him

items.synopsis: Predicting the shape and outcome of future wars is all but impossible. What matters is the ability to learn and adapt better than an adversary and that is Ukraine's next challenge, writes Mick Ryan.

title.children: Russia's war tactics keep evolving. If Ukraine is to emerge victorious, it needs to be faster

image.altText: A white man with no hair, dressed in a suit, sits behind a microphone with a concerned expression.

items.synopsis: The executives of one of Australia's leading consultancy firms are criticised for their unwillingness to share information and how they handle complaints of misconduct.

title.children: Deloitte CEO admits he should not be paid seven times as much as PM during Senate grilling

image.altText: police some holding rifles and others crouching behind cars attend a siege situation in a town in new south wales

items.synopsis: Police believe the 29-year-old man died from a self-inflicted gunshot wound after they tried to negotiate with him from about midday on Sunday.

title.children: Man dies from gunshot wound after 21-hour siege with NSW police

image.altText: Nicola Gobbo stands with her arms crossed with a black background

items.synopsis: Thirty-eight of Victoria's most eminent legal practitioners have signed a letter condemning the comments of Premier Daniel Andrews and calling for a public apology following the closure of the special investigative office set up to probe the Lawyer X scandal.

title.children: Barristers condemn Daniel Andrews's comments over Lawyer X special investigation

image.altText: People stand around a large object on a beach

items.synopsis: The object, which washed up at Green Head — 250km north of Perth — is being treated as hazardous until its origins can be established.

title.children: Australian Space Agency says mysterious item on WA beach could be 'foreign' rocket part

image.altText: A man in a blue shirt tries to reach a camel in a red dirt arena

items.synopsis: A record crowd flocks to outback Queensland to watch Joe Blows try and stick duct tape on feisty camels while avoiding their kicking legs.

title.children: Chasing camels to stick duct tape on their backs a wacky competition attracting thousands

image.altText: A mobile phone is held in a person's hand at the ASX in Sydney

items.synopsis: Wall Street gained on optimism about good company profit results and the ASX is set to fall. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: US stocks rally on company profit hopes, RBA minutes in focus, ASX set to fall

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Outgoing Reserve Bank governor Philip Lowe says governments need to do more to tackle falling productivity. He's used his final international appearance at a G20 finance meeting in India, alongside Treasurer Jim Chalmers, to warn about slowing productivity growth. Mr Lowe says falling productivity is a bigger challenge than inflation. "The reality that most of us face is that productivity growth has slowed down in most of our economies," he said. "It means lower sustainable growth in real wages, it means a limited increase in output as well." "It means a slower expansion in the public services we want for our society and it means an increased tension in the distribution of income." "So low productivity growth means economic and social problems. " "I agree the immediate consequence and the immediate challenge is to get inflation down." "We really need to be successful there but I think the bigger challenge is to lift productivity growth." Mr Lowe ends his seven year term as Reserve Bank governor in September after he was not reappointed by the Treasurer. His deputy Michele Bullock will become the first women to lead the RBA. Here's more from ABC News.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Philip Lowe says productivity greater challenge than inflation

featuredLink.title: Michele Bullock becomes first woman to serve as RBA governor, replacing Philip Lowe

children.content: Outgoing Reserve Bank governor Philip Lowe says governments need to do more to tackle falling productivity.
He's used his final international appearance at a G20 finance meeting in India, alongside Treasurer Jim Chalmers, to warn about slowing productivity growth.
Mr Lowe says falling productivity is a bigger challenge than inflation.
"The reality that most of us face is that productivity growth has slowed down in most of our economies," he said.
"It means lower sustainable growth in real wages, it means a limited increase in output as well."
"It means a slower expansion in the public services we want for our society and it means an increased tension in the distribution of income."
"So low productivity growth means economic and social problems.
"I agree the immediate consequence and the immediate challenge is to get inflation down."
"We really need to be successful there but I think the bigger challenge is to lift productivity growth."
Mr Lowe ends his seven year term as Reserve Bank governor in September after he was not reappointed by the Treasurer.
His deputy Michele Bullock will become the first women to lead the RBA.
Here's more from ABC News.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Russia has halted a wartime deal that allowed grain to be exported from Ukraine to countries in Africa, the Middle East and Asia. The agreement protects grain exports from being attacked by Russian forces. The deal was brokered by the United Nations and Turkiye in July last year and aims to alleviate a global food crisis. Wheat and corn futures rose to a two week high, before falling back. Russia says the Black Sea Grain Initiative will be suspended until demands to get Russian food and fertiliser to the world are met. The decision came after an attack on a bridge connecting the Crimean Peninsula to Russia, which left two people dead. Moscow has blamed Ukraine for the incident, but Ukraine has not officially claimed responsibility. Ukraine says the grain agreement can function without Russia, while Moscow says it will consider rejoining the pact if it saw "concrete results" on its demands. Analysts say the deal may be renewed and that's why grain prices fell after rising. "I think it's suspended; it's maybe not over", said Shermin Newlin, analyst for Risk Management Commodities. "There's still some hope out there." Food prices could surge for the world's poorest people if the deal is not renewed. Here's more from RN Breakfast:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Wheat prices rise after Russia ends grain deal

featuredLink.title: Russia withdraws from landmark grain deal which allowed Ukraine to export grain - ABC Radio National

children.content: Russia has halted a wartime deal that allowed grain to be exported from Ukraine to countries in Africa, the Middle East and Asia.
The agreement protects grain exports from being attacked by Russian forces.
The deal was brokered by the United Nations and Turkiye in July last year and aims to alleviate a global food crisis.
Wheat and corn futures rose to a two week high, before falling back.
Russia says the Black Sea Grain Initiative will be suspended until demands to get Russian food and fertiliser to the world are met.
The decision came after an attack on a bridge connecting the Crimean Peninsula to Russia, which left two people dead.
Moscow has blamed Ukraine for the incident, but Ukraine has not officially claimed responsibility.
Ukraine says the grain agreement can function without Russia, while Moscow says it will consider rejoining the pact if it saw "concrete results" on its demands.
Analysts say the deal may be renewed and that's why grain prices fell after rising.
"I think it's suspended; it's maybe not over", said Shermin Newlin, analyst for Risk Management Commodities.
"There's still some hope out there."
Food prices could surge for the world's poorest people if the deal is not renewed.
Here's more from RN Breakfast:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning and welcome to the ABC's Markets Blog. Stocks on Wall Street gained overnight on optimism about profit results, despite weaker than expected Chinese growth. The Dow Jones index put on 0.2 per cent, while the Nasdaq rose 0.9 per cent. Wall Street giants set to report this week include Tesla, Bank of America, Morgan Stanley, Goldman Sachs and Netflix. The Australian dollar is down 0.3 per cent to 68.16 US cents, while the ASX SPI 200 looks set to open lower. Coming up today: the minutes from the Reserve Bank meeting earlier this month. We will get the thinking behind the RBA's decision to keep official interest rates on hold at 4.1 per cent. Join us today for all your business and finance news.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US stocks rise on company earnings optimism

children.content: Good morning and welcome to the ABC's Markets Blog.
Stocks on Wall Street gained overnight on optimism about profit results, despite weaker than expected Chinese growth.
The Dow Jones index put on 0.2 per cent, while the Nasdaq rose 0.9 per cent.
Wall Street giants set to report this week include Tesla, Bank of America, Morgan Stanley, Goldman Sachs and Netflix.
The Australian dollar is down 0.3 per cent to 68.16 US cents, while the ASX SPI 200 looks set to open lower.
Coming up today: the minutes from the Reserve Bank meeting earlier this month.
We will get the thinking behind the RBA's decision to keep official interest rates on hold at 4.1 per cent.
Join us today for all your business and finance news.

image.altText: Close up of person with long hair with head bent and two hands covering their face, leaning on their forehead.

title.children: Sophie loved her job, until it made her so anxious she had to quit. She's far from alone

image.altText: A bearded man posing with four children of varying ages including a toddler, in front of a river.

image.altText: dried and pressed specimens of plants taped to a paper. grass and flowering heads are yellow.

title.children: Victorian plant thought extinct for 70 years rediscovered following floods

image.altText: Two women sit side by side in front of a yellow wall. One wears beige zip-up jumper, the other lime-green. Both look serious

items.synopsis: As Cambodian leader Hun Sen prepares to contest a one-sided election, many of his critics have been silenced. But the Friday Women, whose husbands and sons are behind bars, won't let their quiet protest for political freedom be drowned out.

image.altText: A colourful photo of Orange city in the foreground and a mountain in the background.
